title: Fix: Cross-compile setup-tui for Linux
description:
Goal: Cross-compile the setup TUI binary for Linux so it can run inside Docker.

=== CONTEXT: VHS GIF Recording Workflow ===

We record terminal GIFs using VHS. Because VHS is incompatible with macOS sandbox-exec, we run it inside Docker:

1. scripts/vhs-docker.sh runs: docker run --rm -v $PWD:/vhs ghcr.io/charmbracelet/vhs <tape>
2. Docker is Linux. It mounts the repo at /vhs.
3. VHS reads the tape file (e.g., orchestrator/e2e/navigation.tape)
4. The tape says: Type "./setup-tui-linux" and Enter
5. Docker (Linux) tries to execute ./setup-tui-linux
6. THE BINARY MUST BE A LINUX ELF, NOT MACOS MACH-O

Currently setup-tui-linux is a macOS binary (Mach-O arm64). We need to cross-compile it for Linux.

=== YOUR TASK ===

1. Find the Go source for the setup TUI (check orchestrator/cmd/setup/)
2. Cross-compile for Linux:
   export GOPATH="$(pwd)/.go-cache"
   export GOCACHE="$(pwd)/.go-build-cache"
   GOOS=linux GOARCH=amd64 go build -o setup-tui-linux ./orchestrator/cmd/setup
3. Verify: file setup-tui-linux should show "ELF 64-bit LSB executable"

title: Epic: CI-Gated VHS Testing Infrastructure
description:
Goal: Move VHS terminal recording from local Docker to GitHub Actions for reliability and speed.

=== THE PROBLEM ===

VHS (terminal GIF recorder) has compatibility issues on macOS:
- VHS is incompatible with macOS sandbox-exec (blocks TTY operations)
- Docker VHS works but is slow (~5 mins per tape on ARM Mac with x86 emulation)
- Agents burn time waiting for slow Docker runs

=== THE SOLUTION ===

Run VHS in GitHub Actions on native Linux runners:
1. Agent makes code changes
2. Agent commits and pushes
3. Agent creates a "gate" bead that waits for CI to complete
4. Agent exits (no waiting!)
5. GitHub Action runs VHS on Linux (fast, ~30 sec)
6. CI completes, gate resolves
7. Another agent session evaluates the result

Benefits:
- Native Linux VHS (no Docker overhead)
- Agents dont wait for slow operations
- No macOS sandbox issues
- Keeps dev laptops cool

=== SUBTASKS ===

1. Create GitHub Action workflow for VHS
2. Create gate-check script for orchestrator  
3. Update AGENTS.md with CI-gated workflow instructions
4. Update directive template with gate usage
5. Test end-to-end flow

title: Infra: Create GitHub Action for VHS generation
description:
Goal: Create a GitHub Action workflow that runs VHS on native Linux.

=== CONTEXT ===

VHS runs slowly via Docker on macOS (~5 mins per tape). GitHub Actions provides free Linux runners where VHS runs natively and fast (~30 sec).

The workflow should:
1. Trigger on push (when .tape files or TUI code changes)
2. Build the Linux binary
3. Run all VHS tapes
4. Upload GIFs as artifacts
5. Commit GIFs back to repo (optional) or make available for download

=== YOUR TASK ===

1. Create .github/workflows/vhs.yml:

name: VHS Terminal Recording
on:
  push:
    paths:
      - "orchestrator/**"
      - "**/*.tape"
  workflow_dispatch:

jobs:
  record:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - uses: actions/setup-go@v5
        with:
          go-version: "1.21"
      - name: Install VHS
        run: |
          sudo apt-get update
          sudo apt-get install -y ffmpeg
          go install github.com/charmbracelet/vhs@latest
      - name: Build TUI
        run: go build -o setup-tui-linux ./orchestrator/cmd/setup
      - name: Run VHS tapes
        run: |
          vhs orchestrator/e2e/navigation.tape
          vhs orchestrator/e2e/crud.tape
      - name: Upload GIFs
        uses: actions/upload-artifact@v4
        with:
          name: vhs-gifs
          path: docs/ui-history/*.gif

2. Test by pushing a change and verifying the action runs

Verification:
- Action appears in GitHub Actions tab
- GIFs uploaded as artifacts

title: Infra: Add gate-check to orchestrator
description:
Goal: Add periodic gate checking to the bootstrap orchestrator.

=== CONTEXT ===

Beads has a gate system for async coordination. Gates can wait for external events like GitHub workflow completion (gh:run type). The orchestrator needs to periodically check and resolve gates.

The workflow:
1. Agent commits code, creates a gate waiting for CI
2. Agent exits
3. CI runs VHS on GitHub
4. Gate-check script (run by orchestrator) polls GitHub, resolves gate when CI completes
5. Dependent tasks unblock

=== YOUR TASK ===

1. Create bootstrap/check_gates.sh:

#!/bin/bash
# Check and resolve GitHub workflow gates
# Run every 5 minutes from the orchestrator

# Check for open gates
OPEN_GATES=$(bd gate list --json 2>/dev/null | jq -r ".[] | select(.status == \"open\")")

if [ -z "$OPEN_GATES" ]; then
    exit 0
fi

# Use bd gate check to evaluate gates
bd gate check --type=gh:run 2>/dev/null || true

2. Modify orchestrator_with_quota.sh to call check_gates.sh every 5 cycles:

# Add near the top of the main loop:
if [ $((count % 5)) -eq 0 ]; then
    ./bootstrap/check_gates.sh
fi

Verification:
- check_gates.sh runs without error
- bd gate list shows gates being checked

title: Docs: Update AGENTS.md with CI-gated workflow
description:
Goal: Document the CI-gated workflow in AGENTS.md so agents know how to use it.

=== CONTEXT ===

For slow operations (VHS recording, expensive tests), agents should use the CI-gated workflow:
1. Make changes and commit
2. Create a gate that waits for CI
3. Exit immediately (dont wait)
4. The gate automatically resolves when CI completes
5. Next agent session can evaluate the result

This avoids agents sitting idle waiting for slow Docker operations.

=== YOUR TASK ===

Add a new section to AGENTS.md after "System-Wide Installations":

## CI-Gated Operations

Some operations run faster on CI than locally:
- VHS terminal recording (uses Docker locally, native Linux on CI)
- Heavy test suites

For these operations, use the CI-gated workflow:

1. **Make your changes** and commit:
   git add -A && git commit -m "feat: update TUI layout" && git push

2. **Create a gate** that waits for the CI workflow:
   bd create --type=gate --title="Wait for VHS CI" --external-ref="gh:run:vhs"

3. **Link your follow-up task** to the gate:
   bd dep add <follow-up-task> <gate-id>

4. **Exit immediately** - the orchestrator will check gates periodically

5. **When CI completes**, the gate resolves and the follow-up task unblocks

This keeps your laptop cool and your quota efficient!

- Instructions are clear and complete

Goal: Implement the Gemini Account Pooling structure from architecture-vision.md.

Specs:
1. Create directory structure: ~/.machinator/accounts/default/
2. Each account subdirectory contains its own gemini config symlink/copy.
3. Add to Setup TUI: 'Manage Accounts' option.
4. Initial implementation: just 'default' account. Multi-account is future work.

Files:
- orchestrator/pkg/setup/accounts.go (new - account management logic)
- orchestrator/pkg/setup/model.go (add accounts menu item)

Verification:
- Run setup, verify 'Manage Accounts' appears in menu.
- ~/.machinator/accounts/default/ directory exists after first run.

Safety:
- Do NOT delete or modify existing ~/.gemini. Only create new structure.
- If this requires significant TUI changes, split into subtasks.
